76struct hash_table;
77typedef struct hash_table group_hash_t;
78typedef struct hash_table universe_hash_t;
79typedef struct hash_table option_name_hash_t;
80typedef struct hash_table option_code_hash_t;
81typedef struct hash_table dns_zone_hash_t;
82typedef struct hash_table lease_ip_hash_t;
83typedef struct hash_table lease_id_hash_t;
84typedef struct hash_table host_hash_t;
85typedef struct hash_table class_hash_t;

109
110#if !defined (BYTE_NAME_HASH_SIZE)
111# define BYTE_NAME_HASH_SIZE 401 /* Default would be ridiculous. */
112#endif
113#if !defined (BYTE_CODE_HASH_SIZE)
114# define BYTE_CODE_HASH_SIZE 254 /* Default would be ridiculous. */
115#endif
116
117/* Although it is highly improbable that a 16-bit option space might
118 * actually use 2^16 actual defined options, it is the worst case
119 * scenario we must prepare for. Having 4 options per bucket in this
120 * case is pretty reasonable.
121 */
122#if !defined (WORD_NAME_HASH_SIZE)
123# define WORD_NAME_HASH_SIZE 20479
124#endif
125#if !defined (WORD_CODE_HASH_SIZE)
126# define WORD_CODE_HASH_SIZE 16384
127#endif
128
129/* Not only is it improbable that the 32-bit spaces might actually use 2^32
130 * defined options, it is infeasible. It would be best for this kind of
131 * space to be dynamically sized. Instead we size it at the word hash's
132 * level.
133 */
134#if !defined (QUAD_NAME_HASH_SIZE)
135# define QUAD_NAME_HASH_SIZE WORD_NAME_HASH_SIZE
136#endif
137#if !defined (QUAD_CODE_HASH_SIZE)
138# define QUAD_CODE_HASH_SIZE WORD_CODE_HASH_SIZE
139#endif
140
141#if !defined (DNS_HASH_SIZE)
142# define DNS_HASH_SIZE 0 /* Default. */
143#endif
144
145/* Default size to use for name/code hashes on user-defined option spaces. */
146#if !defined (DEFAULT_SPACE_HASH_SIZE)
147# define DEFAULT_SPACE_HASH_SIZE 11
148#endif
149
150#if !defined (NWIP_HASH_SIZE)
151# define NWIP_HASH_SIZE 17 /* A really small table. */
152#endif
153
154#if !defined (FQDN_HASH_SIZE)
155# define FQDN_HASH_SIZE 13 /* A ridiculously small table. */
156#endif
157
158/* I really doubt a given installation is going to have more than a few
159 * hundred vendors involved.
160 */
161#if !defined (VIVCO_HASH_SIZE)
162# define VIVCO_HASH_SIZE 127
163#endif
164
165#if !defined (VIVSO_HASH_SIZE)
166# define VIVSO_HASH_SIZE VIVCO_HASH_SIZE
167#endif
168
169#if !defined (VSIO_HASH_SIZE)
170# define VSIO_HASH_SIZE VIVCO_HASH_SIZE
171#endif
172
173#if !defined (VIV_ISC_HASH_SIZE)
174# define VIV_ISC_HASH_SIZE 3 /* An incredulously small table. */
175#endif
176
177#if !defined (UNIVERSE_HASH_SIZE)
178# define UNIVERSE_HASH_SIZE 13 /* A really small table. */
179#endif
180
181#if !defined (GROUP_HASH_SIZE)
182# define GROUP_HASH_SIZE 0 /* Default. */
183#endif
184
185/* At least one person has indicated they use ~20k host records.
186 */
187#if !defined (HOST_HASH_SIZE)
188# define HOST_HASH_SIZE 22501
189#endif
190
191/* We have user reports of use of ISC DHCP numbering leases in the 200k's.
192 *
193 * We also have reports of folks using 10.0/8 as a dynamic range. The
194 * following is something of a compromise between the two. At the ~2-3
195 * hundred thousand leases, there's ~2-3 leases to search in each bucket.
196 */
197#if !defined (LEASE_HASH_SIZE)
198# define LEASE_HASH_SIZE 100003
199#endif
200
201/* It is not known what the worst case subclass hash size is. We estimate
202 * high, I think.
203 */
204#if !defined (SCLASS_HASH_SIZE)
205# define SCLASS_HASH_SIZE 12007
206#endif
207
208#if !defined (AGENT_HASH_SIZE)
209# define AGENT_HASH_SIZE 11 /* A really small table. */
210#endif
211
212/* The server hash size is used for both names and codes. There aren't
213 * many (roughly 50 at the moment), so we use a smaller table. If we
214 * use a 1:1 table size, then we get name collisions due to poor name
215 * hashing. So we use double the space we need, which drastically
216 * reduces collisions.
217 */
218#if !defined (SERVER_HASH_SIZE)
219# define SERVER_HASH_SIZE (2*(sizeof(server_options) / sizeof(struct option)))
220#endif
221
222
223/* How many options are likely to appear in a single packet? */
224#if !defined (OPTION_HASH_SIZE)
225# define OPTION_HASH_SIZE 17
226# define OPTION_HASH_PTWO 32 /* Next power of two above option hash. */
227# define OPTION_HASH_EXP 5 /* The exponent for that power of two. */
228#endif
229
230#define compute_option_hash(x) \
231 (((x) & (OPTION_HASH_PTWO - 1)) + \
232 (((x) >> OPTION_HASH_EXP) & \
233 (OPTION_HASH_PTWO - 1))) % OPTION_HASH_SIZE;
234
235/* Lease queue information. We have two ways of storing leases.
236 * The original is a linear linked list which is slower but uses
237 * less memory while the other adds a binary array on top of that
238 * list to make insertions faster. We define several macros
239 * based on which is in use to allow the code to be cleaner by
240 * avoiding #ifdefs.
241 *
242 * POOL_DESTROYP is used for cleanup
243 */
244
245#if !defined (BINARY_LEASES)
246#define LEASE_STRUCT struct lease *
247#define LEASE_STRUCT_PTR struct lease **
248#define LEASE_GET_FIRST(LQ) LQ
249#define LEASE_GET_FIRSTP(LQ) *(LQ)
250#define LEASE_GET_NEXT(LQ, LEASE) LEASE->next
251#define LEASE_GET_NEXTP(LQ, LEASE) LEASE->next
252#define LEASE_INSERTP(LQ, LEASE) lease_insert(LQ, LEASE)
253#define LEASE_REMOVEP(LQ, LEASE) lease_remove(LQ, LEASE)
254#define LEASE_NOT_EMPTY(LQ) LQ
255#define LEASE_NOT_EMPTYP(LQ) *LQ
256#define POOL_DESTROYP(LQ) lease_remove_all(LQ)
257#else
258#define LEASE_STRUCT struct leasechain
259#define LEASE_STRUCT_PTR struct leasechain *
260#define LEASE_GET_FIRST(LQ) lc_get_first_lease(&LQ)
261#define LEASE_GET_FIRSTP(LQ) lc_get_first_lease(LQ)
262#define LEASE_GET_NEXT(LQ, LEASE) lc_get_next(&LQ, LEASE)
263#define LEASE_GET_NEXTP(LQ, LEASE) lc_get_next(LQ, LEASE)
264#define LEASE_INSERTP(LQ, LEASE) lc_add_sorted_lease(LQ, LEASE)
265#define LEASE_REMOVEP(LQ, LEASE) lc_unlink_lease(LQ, LEASE)
266#define LEASE_NOT_EMPTY(LQ) lc_not_empty(&LQ)
267#define LEASE_NOT_EMPTYP(LQ) lc_not_empty(LQ)
268#define POOL_DESTROYP(LQ) lc_delete_all(LQ)
269#endif
270
271enum dhcp_shutdown_state {
272 shutdown_listeners,
273 shutdown_omapi_connections,
274 shutdown_drop_omapi_connections,
275 shutdown_dhcp,
276 shutdown_done
277};
278
279/* Client FQDN option, failover FQDN option, etc. */
280typedef struct {
281 u_int8_t codes [2];
282 unsigned length;
283 u_int8_t *data;
284} ddns_fqdn_t;
285
286#include "failover.h"
287
288/* A parsing context. */
289
290struct parse {
291 int lexline;
292 int lexchar;
293 char *token_line;
294 char *prev_line;
295 char *cur_line;
296 const char *tlname;
297 int eol_token;
298
299 /*
300 * In order to give nice output when we have a parsing error
301 * in our file, we keep track of where we are in the line so
302 * that we can show the user.
303 *
304 * We need to keep track of two lines, because we can look
305 * ahead, via the "peek" function, to the next line sometimes.
306 *
307 * The "line1" and "line2" variables act as buffers for this
308 * information. The "lpos" variable tells us where we are in the
309 * line.
310 *
311 * When we "put back" a character from the parsing context, we
312 * do not want to have the character appear twice in the error
313 * output. So, we set a flag, the "ugflag", which the
314 * get_char() function uses to check for this condition.
315 */
316 char line1 [81];
317 char line2 [81];
318 int lpos;
319 int line;
320 int tlpos;
321 int tline;
322 enum dhcp_token token;
323 int ugflag;
324 char *tval;
325 int tlen;
326 char tokbuf [1500];
327
328 int warnings_occurred;
329 int file;
330 char *inbuf;
331 size_t bufix, buflen;
332 size_t bufsiz;
333
334 struct parse *saved_state;
335
336#if defined(LDAP_CONFIGURATION)
337 /*
338 * LDAP configuration uses a call-back to iteratively read config
339 * off of the LDAP repository.
340 * XXX: The token stream can not be rewound reliably, so this must
341 * be addressed for DHCPv6 support.
342 */
343 int (*read_function)(struct parse *);
344#endif
345};
346
347/* Variable-length array of data. */
348
349struct string_list {
350 struct string_list *next;
351 char string [1];
352};
353
354/* A name server, from /etc/resolv.conf. */
355struct name_server {
356 struct name_server *next;
357 struct sockaddr_in addr;
358 TIME rcdate;
359};
360
361/* A domain search list element. */
362struct domain_search_list {
363 struct domain_search_list *next;
364 char *domain;
365 TIME rcdate;
366};
367
368/* Option tag structures are used to build chains of option tags, for
369 when we're sure we're not going to have enough of them to justify
370 maintaining an array. */
371
372struct option_tag {
373 struct option_tag *next;
374 u_int8_t data [1];
375};
376
377/* An agent option structure. We need a special structure for the
378 Relay Agent Information option because if more than one appears in
379 a message, we have to keep them separate. */
380
381struct agent_options {
382 struct agent_options *next;
383 int length;
384 struct option_tag *first;
385};
386
387struct option_cache {
388 int refcnt;
389 struct option_cache *next;
390 struct expression *expression;
391 struct option *option;
392 struct data_string data;
393
394 #define OPTION_HAD_NULLS 0x00000001
395 u_int32_t flags;
396};
397
398struct option_state {
399 int refcnt;
400 int universe_count;
401 int site_universe;
402 int site_code_min;
403 void *universes [1];
404};
405
406/* A dhcp packet and the pointers to its option values. */
407struct packet {
408 struct dhcp_packet *raw;
409 int refcnt;
410 unsigned packet_length;
411 int packet_type;
412
413 unsigned char dhcpv6_msg_type; /* DHCPv6 message type */
414
415 /* DHCPv6 transaction ID */
416 unsigned char dhcpv6_transaction_id[3];
417
418 /* DHCPv6 relay information */
419 unsigned char dhcpv6_hop_count;
420 struct in6_addr dhcpv6_link_address;
421 struct in6_addr dhcpv6_peer_address;
422
423 /* DHCPv6 packet containing this one, or NULL if none */
424 struct packet *dhcpv6_container_packet;
425
426 /* DHCPv4-over-DHCPv6 flags */
427 unsigned char dhcp4o6_flags[3];
428
429 /* DHCPv4-over-DHCPv6 response, or NULL */
430 struct data_string *dhcp4o6_response;
431
432 int options_valid;
433 int client_port;
434 struct iaddr client_addr;
435 struct interface_info *interface; /* Interface on which packet
436 was received. */
437 struct hardware *haddr; /* Physical link address
438 of local sender (maybe gateway). */
439
440 /* Information for relay agent options (see
441 draft-ietf-dhc-agent-options-xx.txt). */
442 u_int8_t *circuit_id; /* Circuit ID of client connection. */
443 int circuit_id_len;
444 u_int8_t *remote_id; /* Remote ID of client. */
445 int remote_id_len;
446
447 int got_requested_address; /* True if client sent the
448 dhcp-requested-address option. */
449
450 struct shared_network *shared_network;
451 struct option_state *options;
452
453#if !defined (PACKET_MAX_CLASSES)
454# define PACKET_MAX_CLASSES 5
455#endif
456 int class_count;
457 struct class *classes [PACKET_MAX_CLASSES];
458
459 int known;
460 int authenticated;
461
462 /* If we stash agent options onto the packet option state, to pretend
463 * options we got in a previous exchange were still there, we need
464 * to signal this in a reliable way.
465 */
466 isc_boolean_t agent_options_stashed;
467
468 /*
469 * ISC_TRUE if packet received unicast (as opposed to multicast).
470 * Only used in DHCPv6.
471 */
472 isc_boolean_t unicast;
473
474 /* Propagates server value SV_ECHO_CLIENT_ID so it is available
475 * in cons_options() */
476 int sv_echo_client_id;
477
478 /* Relay port check */
479 isc_boolean_t relay_source_port;
480};
481
482/*
483 * A network interface's MAC address.
484 * 20 bytes for the hardware address
485 * and 1 byte for the type tag
486 */
487
488#define HARDWARE_ADDR_LEN 20
489
490struct hardware {
491 u_int8_t hlen;
492 u_int8_t hbuf[HARDWARE_ADDR_LEN + 1];
493};
494
495#if defined(LDAP_CONFIGURATION)
496# define LDAP_BUFFER_SIZE 8192
497# define LDAP_METHOD_STATIC 0
498# define LDAP_METHOD_DYNAMIC 1
499#if defined (LDAP_USE_SSL)
500# define LDAP_SSL_OFF 0
501# define LDAP_SSL_ON 1
502# define LDAP_SSL_TLS 2
503# define LDAP_SSL_LDAPS 3
504#endif
505
506/* This is a tree of the current configuration we are building from LDAP */
507struct ldap_config_stack {
508 LDAPMessage * res; /* Pointer returned from ldap_search */
509 LDAPMessage * ldent; /* Current item in LDAP that we're processing.
510 in res */
511 int close_brace; /* Put a closing } after we're through with
512 this item */
513 int processed; /* We set this flag if this base item has been
514 processed. After this base item is processed,
515 we can start processing the children */
516 struct ldap_config_stack *children;
517 struct ldap_config_stack *next;
518};
519#endif

521typedef enum {
522 server_startup = 0,
523 server_running = 1,
524 server_shutdown = 2,
525 server_hibernate = 3,
526 server_awaken = 4
527} control_object_state_t;
528
529typedef struct {
530 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
531 control_object_state_t state;
532} dhcp_control_object_t;
533
534/* Lease states: */
535#define FTS_FREE 1
536#define FTS_ACTIVE 2
537#define FTS_EXPIRED 3
538#define FTS_RELEASED 4
539#define FTS_ABANDONED 5
540#define FTS_RESET 6
541#define FTS_BACKUP 7
542typedef u_int8_t binding_state_t;
543
544/* FTS_LAST is the highest value that is valid for a lease binding state. */
545#define FTS_LAST FTS_BACKUP
546
547/*
548 * A block for the on statements so we can share the structure
549 * between v4 and v6
550 */
551struct on_star {
552 struct executable_statement *on_expiry;
553 struct executable_statement *on_commit;
554 struct executable_statement *on_release;
555};
556
557/* A dhcp lease declaration structure. */
558struct lease {
559 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
560 struct lease *next;
561#if defined (BINARY_LEASES)
562 struct lease *prev;
563 struct leasechain *lc;
564#endif
565 struct lease *n_uid, *n_hw;
566
567 struct iaddr ip_addr;
568 TIME starts, ends, sort_time;
569#if defined (BINARY_LEASES)
570 long int sort_tiebreaker;
571#endif
572 char *client_hostname;
573 struct binding_scope *scope;
574 struct host_decl *host;
575 struct subnet *subnet;
576 struct pool *pool;
577 struct class *billing_class;
578 struct option_chain_head *agent_options;
579
580 /* insert the structure directly */
581 struct on_star on_star;
582
583 unsigned char *uid;
584 unsigned short uid_len;
585 unsigned short uid_max;
586 unsigned char uid_buf [7];
587 struct hardware hardware_addr;
588
589 u_int8_t flags;
590# define STATIC_LEASE 1
591# define BOOTP_LEASE 2
592# define RESERVED_LEASE 4
593# define MS_NULL_TERMINATION 8
594# define ON_UPDATE_QUEUE 16
595# define ON_ACK_QUEUE 32
596# define ON_QUEUE (ON_UPDATE_QUEUE | ON_ACK_QUEUE)
597# define UNICAST_BROADCAST_HACK 64
598# define ON_DEFERRED_QUEUE 128
599
600/* Persistent flags are to be preserved on a given lease structure. */
601# define PERSISTENT_FLAGS (ON_ACK_QUEUE | ON_UPDATE_QUEUE)
602/* Ephemeral flags are to be preserved on a given lease (copied etc). */
603# define EPHEMERAL_FLAGS (MS_NULL_TERMINATION | \
604 UNICAST_BROADCAST_HACK | \
605 RESERVED_LEASE | \
606 BOOTP_LEASE)
607
608 /*
609 * The lease's binding state is its current state. The next binding
610 * state is the next state this lease will move into by expiration,
611 * or timers in general. The desired binding state is used on lease
612 * updates; the caller is attempting to move the lease to the desired
613 * binding state (and this may either succeed or fail, so the binding
614 * state must be preserved).
615 *
616 * The 'rewind' binding state is used in failover processing. It
617 * is used for an optimization when out of communications; it allows
618 * the server to "rewind" a lease to the previous state acknowledged
619 * by the peer, and progress forward from that point.
620 */
621 binding_state_t binding_state;
622 binding_state_t next_binding_state;
623 binding_state_t desired_binding_state;
624 binding_state_t rewind_binding_state;
625
626 struct lease_state *state;
627
628 /*
629 * 'tsfp' is more of an 'effective' tsfp. It may be calculated from
630 * stos+mclt for example if it's an expired lease and the server is
631 * in partner-down state. 'atsfp' is zeroed whenever a lease is
632 * updated - and only set when the peer acknowledges it. This
633 * ensures every state change is transmitted.
634 */
635 TIME tstp; /* Time sent to partner. */
636 TIME tsfp; /* Time sent from partner. */
637 TIME atsfp; /* Actual time sent from partner. */
638 TIME cltt; /* Client last transaction time. */
639 u_int32_t last_xid; /* XID we sent in this lease's BNDUPD */
640 struct lease *next_pending;
641
642 /*
643 * A pointer to the state of the ddns update for this lease.
644 * It should be set while the update is in progress and cleared
645 * when the update finishes. It can be used to cancel the
646 * update if we want to do a different update.
647 */
648 struct dhcp_ddns_cb *ddns_cb;
649
650 /* Set when a lease has been disqualified for cache-threshold reuse */
651 unsigned short cannot_reuse;
652};
653
654struct lease_state {
655 struct lease_state *next;
656
657 struct interface_info *ip;
658
659 struct packet *packet; /* The incoming packet. */
660
661 TIME offered_expiry;
662
663 struct option_state *options;
664 struct data_string parameter_request_list;
665 int max_message_size;
666 unsigned char expiry[4], renewal[4], rebind[4];
667 struct data_string filename, server_name;
668 int got_requested_address;
669 int got_server_identifier;
670 struct shared_network *shared_network; /* Shared network of interface
671 on which request arrived. */
672
673 u_int32_t xid;
674 u_int16_t secs;
675 u_int16_t bootp_flags;
676 struct in_addr ciaddr;
677 struct in_addr siaddr;
678 struct in_addr giaddr;
679 u_int8_t hops;
680 u_int8_t offer;
681 struct iaddr from;
682};

704#define DDNS_UPDATE_STYLE_INTERIM 2
705#define DDNS_UPDATE_STYLE_STANDARD 3

707/* Server option names. */
708
709#define SV_DEFAULT_LEASE_TIME 1
710#define SV_MAX_LEASE_TIME 2
711#define SV_MIN_LEASE_TIME 3
712#define SV_BOOTP_LEASE_CUTOFF 4
713#define SV_BOOTP_LEASE_LENGTH 5
714#define SV_BOOT_UNKNOWN_CLIENTS 6
715#define SV_DYNAMIC_BOOTP 7
716#define SV_ALLOW_BOOTP 8
717#define SV_ALLOW_BOOTING 9
718#define SV_ONE_LEASE_PER_CLIENT 10
719#define SV_GET_LEASE_HOSTNAMES 11
720#define SV_USE_HOST_DECL_NAMES 12
721#define SV_USE_LEASE_ADDR_FOR_DEFAULT_ROUTE 13
722#define SV_MIN_SECS 14
723#define SV_FILENAME 15
724#define SV_SERVER_NAME 16
725#define SV_NEXT_SERVER 17
726#define SV_AUTHORITATIVE 18
727#define SV_VENDOR_OPTION_SPACE 19
728#define SV_ALWAYS_REPLY_RFC1048 20
729#define SV_SITE_OPTION_SPACE 21
730#define SV_ALWAYS_BROADCAST 22
731#define SV_DDNS_DOMAIN_NAME 23
732#define SV_DDNS_HOST_NAME 24
733#define SV_DDNS_REV_DOMAIN_NAME 25

933struct group_object {
934 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
935
936 struct group_object *n_dynamic;
937 struct group *group;
938 char *name;
939 int flags;
940#define GROUP_OBJECT_DELETED 1
941#define GROUP_OBJECT_DYNAMIC 2
942#define GROUP_OBJECT_STATIC 4
943};
944
945/* Group of declarations that share common parameters. */
946struct group {
947 struct group *next;
948
949 int refcnt;
950 struct group_object *object;
951 struct subnet *subnet;
952 struct shared_network *shared_network;
953 int authoritative;
954 struct executable_statement *statements;
955};
956
957/* A dhcp host declaration structure. */
958struct host_decl {
959 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
960 struct host_decl *n_ipaddr;
961 struct host_decl *n_dynamic;
962 char *name;
963 struct hardware interface;
964 struct data_string client_identifier;
965 struct option *host_id_option;
966 struct data_string host_id;
967 /* XXXSK: fixed_addr should be an array of iaddr values,
968 not an option_cache, but it's referenced in a lot of
969 places, so we'll leave it for now. */
970 struct option_cache *fixed_addr;
971 struct iaddrcidrnetlist *fixed_prefix;
972 struct group *group;
973 struct group_object *named_group;
974 struct data_string auth_key_id;
975 int flags;
976#define HOST_DECL_DELETED 1
977#define HOST_DECL_DYNAMIC 2
978#define HOST_DECL_STATIC 4
979 /* For v6 the host-identifer option can specify which relay
980 to use when trying to look up an option. We store the
981 value here. */
982 int relays;
983};
984
985struct permit {
986 struct permit *next;
987 enum {
988 permit_unknown_clients,
989 permit_known_clients,
990 permit_authenticated_clients,
991 permit_unauthenticated_clients,
992 permit_all_clients,
993 permit_dynamic_bootp_clients,
994 permit_class,
995 permit_after
996 } type;
997 struct class *class;
998 TIME after; /* date after which this clause applies */
999};

1001#if defined (BINARY_LEASES)
1002struct leasechain {
1003 struct lease **list; /* lease list */
1004 size_t total; /* max number of elements in this list,
1005 * including free pointers at the end if any */
1006 size_t nelem; /* the number of elements, also the next index to use */
1007 size_t growth; /* the growth factor to use when increase an array
1008 * this is set after parsing the pools and before
1009 * creatin an array. */
1010};
1011#endif

1013struct pool {
1014 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
1015 struct pool *next;
1016 struct group *group;
1017 struct shared_network *shared_network;
1018 struct permit *permit_list;
1019 struct permit *prohibit_list;
1020 LEASE_STRUCT active;
1021 LEASE_STRUCT expired;
1022 LEASE_STRUCT free;
1023 LEASE_STRUCT backup;
1024 LEASE_STRUCT abandoned;
1025 LEASE_STRUCT reserved;
1026 TIME next_event_time;
1027 int lease_count;
1028 int free_leases;
1029 int backup_leases;
1030 int index;
1031 TIME valid_from; /* deny pool use before this date */
1032 TIME valid_until; /* deny pool use after this date */
1033
1034#if defined (FAILOVER_PROTOCOL)
1035 dhcp_failover_state_t *failover_peer;
1036#endif
1037 int logged; /* already logged a message */
1038 int low_threshold; /* low threshold to restart logging */
1039};

1045
1046#define SHARED_IMPLICIT 1 /* This network was synthesized. */
1047 int flags;
1048
1049 struct subnet *subnets;
1050 struct interface_info *interface;
1051 struct pool *pools;
1052 struct ipv6_pond *ipv6_pond;
1053 struct group *group;
1054#if defined (FAILOVER_PROTOCOL)
1055 dhcp_failover_state_t *failover_peer;
1056#endif
1057};

1059struct subnet {

1069 struct group *group;
1070};

1072struct collection {
1073 struct collection *next;
1074
1075 const char *name;
1076 struct class *classes;
1077};
1078
1079/* Used as an argument to parse_clasS_decl() */
1080#define CLASS_TYPE_VENDOR 0
1081#define CLASS_TYPE_USER 1
1082#define CLASS_TYPE_CLASS 2
1083#define CLASS_TYPE_SUBCLASS 3
1084
1085/* XXX classes must be reference-counted. */
1086struct class {
1087 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
1088 struct class *nic; /* Next in collection. */
1089 struct class *superclass; /* Set for spawned classes only. */
1090 char *name; /* Not set for spawned classes. */
1091
1092 /* A class may be configured to permit a limited number of leases. */
1093 int lease_limit;
1094 int leases_consumed;
1095 struct lease **billed_leases;
1096
1097 /* If nonzero, class has not been saved since it was last
1098 modified. */
1099 int dirty;
1100
1101 /* Hash table containing subclasses. */
1102 class_hash_t *hash;
1103 struct data_string hash_string;
1104
1105 /* Expression used to match class. */
1106 struct expression *expr;
1107
1108 /* Expression used to compute subclass identifiers for spawning
1109 and to do subclass matching. */
1110 struct expression *submatch;
1111 int spawning;
1112
1113 struct group *group;
1114
1115 /* Statements to execute if class matches. */
1116 struct executable_statement *statements;
1117
1118#define CLASS_DECL_DELETED 1
1119#define CLASS_DECL_DYNAMIC 2
1120#define CLASS_DECL_STATIC 4
1121#define CLASS_DECL_SUBCLASS 8
1122
1123 int flags;
1124};
1125
1126/* DHCP client lease structure... */
1127struct client_lease {
1128 struct client_lease *next; /* Next lease in list. */
1129 TIME expiry, renewal, rebind; /* Lease timeouts. */
1130 struct iaddr address; /* Address being leased. */
1131 char *server_name; /* Name of boot server. */
1132 char *filename; /* Name of file we're supposed to boot. */
1133 struct string_list *medium; /* Network medium. */
1134 struct auth_key *key; /* Key used in basic DHCP authentication. */
1135
1136 unsigned int is_static : 1; /* If set, lease is from config file. */
1137 unsigned int is_bootp: 1; /* If set, lease was acquired with BOOTP. */
1138
1139 struct option_state *options; /* Options supplied with lease. */
1140 struct iaddr next_srv_addr; /* Address of the next server to use */
1141};
1142
1143/* DHCPv6 lease structures */
1144struct dhc6_addr {
1145 struct dhc6_addr *next;
1146 struct iaddr address;
1147 u_int8_t plen;
1148
1149 /* Address state flags. */
1150 #define DHC6_ADDR_DEPREFFED 0x01
1151 #define DHC6_ADDR_EXPIRED 0x02
1152 #define DHC6_ADDR_DECLINED 0x04
1153 u_int8_t flags;
1154
1155 TIME starts;
1156 u_int32_t preferred_life;
1157 u_int32_t max_life;
1158
1159 struct option_state *options;
1160};
1161
1162struct dhc6_ia {
1163 struct dhc6_ia *next;
1164 unsigned char iaid[4];
1165 u_int16_t ia_type;
1166
1167 TIME starts;
1168 u_int32_t renew;
1169 u_int32_t rebind;
1170 struct dhc6_addr *addrs;
1171
1172 struct option_state *options;
1173};
1174
1175struct dhc6_lease {
1176 struct dhc6_lease *next;
1177 struct data_string server_id;
1178
1179 isc_boolean_t released;
1180 int score;
1181 u_int8_t pref;
1182
1183 unsigned char dhcpv6_transaction_id[3];
1184 struct dhc6_ia *bindings;
1185
1186 struct option_state *options;
1187};
1188
1189/* Possible states in which the client can be. */
1190enum dhcp_state {
1191 S_REBOOTING = 1,
1192 S_INIT = 2,
1193 S_SELECTING = 3,
1194 S_REQUESTING = 4,
1195 S_BOUND = 5,
1196 S_RENEWING = 6,
1197 S_REBINDING = 7,
1198 S_DECLINING = 8,
1199 S_STOPPED = 9
1200};
1201
1202/* Possible pending client operations. */
1203enum dhcp_pending {
1204 P_NONE = 0,
1205 P_REBOOT = 1,
1206 P_RELEASE = 2
1207};
1208
1209/* Authentication and BOOTP policy possibilities (not all values work
1210 for each). */
1211enum policy { P_IGNORE, P_ACCEPT, P_PREFER, P_REQUIRE, P_DONT };
1212
1213/* Configuration information from the config file... */
1214struct client_config {
1215 /*
1216 * When a message has been received, run these statements
1217 * over it.
1218 */
1219 struct group *on_receipt;
1220
1221 /*
1222 * When a message is sent, run these statements.
1223 */
1224 struct group *on_transmission;
1225
1226 struct option **required_options; /* Options that MUST be present. */
1227 struct option **requested_options; /* Options to request (ORO/PRL). */
1228
1229 TIME timeout; /* Start to panic if we don't get a
1230 lease in this time period when
1231 SELECTING. */
1232 TIME initial_delay; /* Set initial delay before first
1233 transmission. */
1234 TIME initial_interval; /* All exponential backoff intervals
1235 start here. */
1236 TIME retry_interval; /* If the protocol failed to produce
1237 an address before the timeout,
1238 try the protocol again after this
1239 many seconds. */
1240 TIME select_interval; /* Wait this many seconds from the
1241 first DHCPDISCOVER before
1242 picking an offered lease. */
1243 TIME reboot_timeout; /* When in INIT-REBOOT, wait this
1244 long before giving up and going
1245 to INIT. */
1246 TIME backoff_cutoff; /* When doing exponential backoff,
1247 never back off to an interval
1248 longer than this amount. */
1249 u_int32_t requested_lease; /* Requested lease time, if user
1250 doesn't configure one. */
1251 struct string_list *media; /* Possible network media values. */
1252 char *script_name; /* Name of config script. */
1253 char *vendor_space_name; /* Name of config script. */
1254 enum policy bootp_policy;
1255 /* Ignore, accept or prefer BOOTP
1256 responses. */
1257 enum policy auth_policy;
1258 /* Require authentication, prefer
1259 authentication, or don't try to
1260 authenticate. */
1261 struct string_list *medium; /* Current network medium. */
1262
1263 struct iaddrmatchlist *reject_list; /* Servers to reject. */
1264
1265 int omapi_port; /* port on which to accept OMAPI
1266 connections, or -1 for no
1267 listener. */
1268 int do_forward_update; /* If nonzero, and if we have the
1269 information we need, update the
1270 A record for the address we get. */
1271
1272 int lease_id_format; /* format for IDs in lease file,
1273 TOKEN_OCTAL or TOKEN_HEX */
1274};
1275
1276/* Per-interface state used in the dhcp client... */
1277/* XXX: consider union {}'ing this for v4/v6. */
1278struct client_state {
1279 struct client_state *next;
1280 struct interface_info *interface;
1281 char *name;
1282
1283 /* Common values. */
1284 struct client_config *config; /* Client configuration. */
1285 struct string_list *env; /* Client script environment. */
1286 int envc; /* Number of entries in environment. */
1287 struct option_state *sent_options; /* Options we sent. */
1288 enum dhcp_state state; /* Current state for this interface. */
1289 TIME last_write; /* Last time this state was written. */
1290 enum dhcp_pending pending; /* Current pending operation. */
1291
1292 /* DHCPv4 values. */
1293 struct client_lease *active; /* Currently active lease. */
1294 struct client_lease *new; /* New lease. */
1295 struct client_lease *offered_leases; /* Leases offered to us. */
1296 struct client_lease *leases; /* Leases we currently hold. */
1297 struct client_lease *alias; /* Alias lease. */
1298
1299 struct iaddr destination; /* Where to send packet. */
1300 u_int32_t xid; /* Transaction ID. */
1301 u_int16_t secs; /* secs value from DHCPDISCOVER. */
1302 TIME first_sending; /* When was first copy sent? */
1303 TIME interval; /* What's the current resend interval? */
1304 struct string_list *medium; /* Last media type tried. */
1305 struct dhcp_packet packet; /* Outgoing DHCP packet. */
1306 unsigned packet_length; /* Actual length of generated packet. */
1307
1308 struct iaddr requested_address; /* Address we would like to get. */
1309
1310 /* DHCPv6 values. */
1311 unsigned char dhcpv6_transaction_id[3];
1312 u_int8_t refresh_type;
1313
1314 struct dhc6_lease *active_lease;
1315 struct dhc6_lease *old_lease;
1316 struct dhc6_lease *advertised_leases;
1317 struct dhc6_lease *selected_lease;
1318 struct dhc6_lease *held_leases;
1319
1320 struct timeval start_time;
1321 u_int16_t elapsed;
1322 int txcount;
1323
1324 /* See RFC3315 section 14. */
1325 TIME RT; /* In hundredths of seconds. */
1326 TIME IRT; /* In hundredths of seconds. */
1327 TIME MRC; /* Count. */
1328 TIME MRT; /* In hundredths of seconds. */
1329 TIME MRD; /* In seconds, relative. */
1330 TIME next_MRD; /* In seconds, absolute. */
1331
1332 /* Rather than a state, we use a function that shifts around
1333 * depending what stage of life the v6 state machine is in.
1334 * This is where incoming packets are dispatched to (sometimes
1335 * a no-op).
1336 */
1337 void (*v6_handler)(struct packet *, struct client_state *);
1338
1339 /*
1340 * A pointer to the state of the ddns update for this lease.
1341 * It should be set while the update is in progress and cleared
1342 * when the update finishes. It can be used to cancel the
1343 * update if we want to do a different update.
1344 */
1345 struct dhcp_ddns_cb *ddns_cb;
1346};
1347
1348struct envadd_state {
1349 struct client_state *client;
1350 const char *prefix;
1351};
1352
1353struct dns_update_state {
1354 struct client_state *client;
1355 struct iaddr address;
1356 int dns_update_timeout;
1357};
1358
1359/* Information about each network interface. */
1360
1361struct interface_info {
1362 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
1363 struct interface_info *next; /* Next interface in list... */
1364 struct shared_network *shared_network;
1365 /* Networks connected to this interface. */
1366 struct hardware hw_address; /* Its physical address. */
1367 struct in_addr *addresses; /* Addresses associated with this
1368 * interface.
1369 */
1370 int address_count; /* Number of addresses stored. */
1371 int address_max; /* Size of addresses buffer. */
1372 struct in6_addr *v6addresses; /* IPv6 addresses associated with
1373 this interface. */
1374 int v6address_count; /* Number of IPv6 addresses associated
1375 with this interface. */
1376 int v6address_max; /* Maximum number of IPv6 addresses
1377 we can store in current buffer. */
1378
1379 u_int8_t *circuit_id; /* Circuit ID associated with this
1380 interface. */
1381 unsigned circuit_id_len; /* Length of Circuit ID, if there
1382 is one. */
1383 u_int8_t *remote_id; /* Remote ID associated with this
1384 interface (if any). */
1385 unsigned remote_id_len; /* Length of Remote ID. */
1386
1387 char name [IFNAMSIZ]; /* Its name... */
1388 int index; /* Its if_nametoindex(). */
1389 int rfdesc; /* Its read file descriptor. */
1390 int wfdesc; /* Its write file descriptor, if
1391 different. */
1392 unsigned char *rbuf; /* Read buffer, if required. */
1393 unsigned int rbuf_max; /* Size of read buffer. */
1394 size_t rbuf_offset; /* Current offset into buffer. */
1395 size_t rbuf_len; /* Length of data in buffer. */
1396
1397 struct ifreq *ifp; /* Pointer to ifreq struct. */
1398 int configured; /* If set to 1, interface has at least
1399 * one valid IP address.
1400 */
1401 u_int32_t flags; /* Control flags... */
1402#define INTERFACE_REQUESTED 1
1403#define INTERFACE_AUTOMATIC 2
1404#define INTERFACE_RUNNING 4
1405#define INTERFACE_DOWNSTREAM 8
1406#define INTERFACE_UPSTREAM 16
1407#define INTERFACE_STREAMS (INTERFACE_DOWNSTREAM | INTERFACE_UPSTREAM)
1408
1409 /* Only used by DHCP client code. */
1410 struct client_state *client;
1411# if defined(USE_DLPI_SEND) || defined(USE_DLPI_RECEIVE) || \
1412 defined(USE_DLPI_HWADDR)
1413 int dlpi_sap_length;
1414 struct hardware dlpi_broadcast_addr;
1415# endif /* DLPI_SEND || DLPI_RECEIVE */
1416 struct hardware anycast_mac_addr;
1417};
1418
1419struct hardware_link {
1420 struct hardware_link *next;
1421 char name [IFNAMSIZ];
1422 struct hardware address;
1423};
1424
1425struct leasequeue {
1426 struct leasequeue *prev;
1427 struct leasequeue *next;
1428 struct lease *lease;
1429};
1430
1431typedef void (*tvref_t)(void *, void *, const char *, int);
1432typedef void (*tvunref_t)(void *, const char *, int);
1433struct timeout {
1434 struct timeout *next;
1435 struct timeval when;
1436 void (*func) (void *);
1437 void *what;
1438 tvref_t ref;
1439 tvunref_t unref;
1440 isc_timer_t *isc_timeout;
1441};
1442
1443struct eventqueue {
1444 struct eventqueue *next;
1445 void (*handler)(void *);
1446};
1447
1448struct protocol {
1449 struct protocol *next;
1450 int fd;
1451 void (*handler) (struct protocol *);
1452 void *local;
1453};
1454
1455struct dns_query; /* forward */
1456
1457struct dns_wakeup {
1458 struct dns_wakeup *next; /* Next wakeup in chain. */
1459 void (*func) (struct dns_query *);
1460};
1461
1462struct dns_question {
1463 u_int16_t type; /* Type of query. */
1464 u_int16_t class; /* Class of query. */
1465 unsigned char data [1]; /* Query data. */
1466};
1467
1468struct dns_answer {
1469 u_int16_t type; /* Type of answer. */
1470 u_int16_t class; /* Class of answer. */
1471 int count; /* Number of answers. */
1472 unsigned char *answers[1]; /* Pointers to answers. */
1473};
1474
1475struct dns_query {
1476 struct dns_query *next; /* Next query in hash bucket. */
1477 u_int32_t hash; /* Hash bucket index. */
1478 TIME expiry; /* Query expiry time (zero if not yet
1479 answered. */
1480 u_int16_t id; /* Query ID (also hash table index) */
1481 caddr_t waiters; /* Pointer to list of things waiting
1482 on this query. */
1483
1484 struct dns_question *question; /* Question, internal format. */
1485 struct dns_answer *answer; /* Answer, internal format. */
1486
1487 unsigned char *query; /* Query formatted for DNS server. */
1488 unsigned len; /* Length of entire query. */
1489 int sent; /* The query has been sent. */
1490 struct dns_wakeup *wakeups; /* Wakeups to call if this query is
1491 answered. */
1492 struct name_server *next_server; /* Next server to try. */
1493 int backoff; /* Current backoff, in seconds. */
1494};
1495
1496#define DNS_ZONE_ACTIVE 0
1497#define DNS_ZONE_INACTIVE 1
1498struct dns_zone {
1499 int refcnt;
1500 TIME timeout;
1501 char *name;
1502 struct option_cache *primary;
1503 struct option_cache *secondary;
1504 struct option_cache *primary6;
1505 struct option_cache *secondary6;
1506 struct auth_key *key;
1507 u_int16_t flags;
1508};
1509
1510struct icmp_state {
1511 OMAPI_OBJECT_PREAMBLE;
1512 int socket;
1513 void (*icmp_handler) (struct iaddr, u_int8_t *, int);
1514};

1516#include "ctrace.h"
1517
1518/* Bitmask of dhcp option codes. */
1519typedef unsigned char option_mask [16];
1520
1521/* DHCP Option mask manipulation macros... */
1522#define OPTION_ZERO(mask) (memset (mask, 0, 16))
1523#define OPTION_SET(mask, bit) (mask [bit >> 8] |= (1 << (bit & 7)))
1524#define OPTION_CLR(mask, bit) (mask [bit >> 8] &= ~(1 << (bit & 7)))
1525#define OPTION_ISSET(mask, bit) (mask [bit >> 8] & (1 << (bit & 7)))
1526#define OPTION_ISCLR(mask, bit) (!OPTION_ISSET (mask, bit))
1527
1528/* An option occupies its length plus two header bytes (code and
1529 length) for every 255 bytes that must be stored. */
1530#define OPTION_SPACE(x) ((x) + 2 * ((x) / 255 + 1))

1608#define INFINITE_TIME 0xffffffff

1618 /* these are referenced */
1619typedef struct hash_table ia_hash_t;
1620typedef struct hash_table iasubopt_hash_t;
1621
1622 /* IAADDR/IAPREFIX lease */
1623
1624struct iasubopt {
1625 int refcnt; /* reference count */
1626 struct in6_addr addr; /* IPv6 address/prefix */
1627 u_int8_t plen; /* iaprefix prefix length */
1628 binding_state_t state; /* state */
1629 struct binding_scope *scope; /* "set var = value;" */
1630 time_t hard_lifetime_end_time; /* time address expires */
1631 time_t soft_lifetime_end_time; /* time ephemeral expires */
1632 u_int32_t prefer; /* cached preferred lifetime */
1633 u_int32_t valid; /* cached valid lifetime */
1634 struct ia_xx *ia; /* IA for this lease */
1635 struct ipv6_pool *ipv6_pool; /* pool for this lease */
1636/*
1637 * For now, just pick an arbitrary time to keep old hard leases
1638 * around (value in seconds).
1639 */
1640#define EXPIRED_IPV6_CLEANUP_TIME (60*60)
1641
1642 /* index into heaps, or -1 (internal use only) */
1643 int active_index;
1644 int inactive_index;
1645
1646 /*
1647 * A pointer to the state of the ddns update for this lease.
1648 * It should be set while the update is in progress and cleared
1649 * when the update finishes. It can be used to cancel the
1650 * update if we want to do a different update.
1651 */
1652 struct dhcp_ddns_cb *ddns_cb;
1653
1654 /* space for the on * executable statements */
1655 struct on_star on_star;
1656 int static_lease;
1657};
1658
1659struct ia_xx {
1660 int refcnt; /* reference count */
1661 struct data_string iaid_duid; /* from the client */
1662 u_int16_t ia_type; /* IA_XX */
1663 int num_iasubopt; /* number of IAADDR/PREFIX */
1664 int max_iasubopt; /* space available for IAADDR/PREFIX */
1665 time_t cltt; /* client last transaction time */
1666 struct iasubopt **iasubopt; /* pointers to the IAADDR/IAPREFIXs */
1667};
1668
1669extern ia_hash_t *ia_na_active;
1670extern ia_hash_t *ia_ta_active;
1671extern ia_hash_t *ia_pd_active;
1672
1673/*!
1674 *
1675 * \brief ipv6_pool structure
1676 *
1677 * This structure is part of a range of addresses or prefixes.
1678 * A range6 or prefix6 statement will map to one or more of these
1679 * with each pool being a simple block of the form xxxx/yyy and
1680 * all the pools adding up to comprise the entire range. When
1681 * choosing an address or prefix the code will walk through the
1682 * pools until it finds one that is available.
1683 *
1684 * The naming for this structure is unfortunate as there is also
1685 * a v4 pool structure and the two are not equivalent. The v4
1686 * pool matches the ipv6_pond structure. I considered changing the
1687 * name of this structure but concluded that doing so would be worse
1688 * than leaving it as is. Changing it adds some risk and makes for
1689 * larger differences between the 4.1 & 4.2 code and the 4.3 code.
1690 *
1691 */
1692
1693struct ipv6_pool {
1694 int refcnt; /* reference count */
1695 u_int16_t pool_type; /* IA_xx */
1696 struct in6_addr start_addr; /* first IPv6 address */
1697 int bits; /* number of bits, CIDR style */
1698 int units; /* allocation unit in bits */
1699 iasubopt_hash_t *leases; /* non-free leases */
1700 isc_uint64_t num_active; /* count of active leases */
1701 isc_uint64_t num_abandoned; /* count of abandoned leases */
1702 isc_heap_t *active_timeouts; /* timeouts for active leases */
1703 int num_inactive; /* count of inactive leases */
1704 isc_heap_t *inactive_timeouts; /* timeouts for expired or
1705 released leases */
1706 struct shared_network *shared_network; /* shared_network for
1707 this pool */
1708 struct subnet *subnet; /* subnet for this pool */
1709 struct ipv6_pond *ipv6_pond; /* pond for this pool */
1710};
1711
1712/*!
1713 *
1714 * \brief ipv6_pond structure
1715 *
1716 * This structure is the ipv6 version of the v4 pool structure.
1717 * It contains the address and prefix information via the pointers
1718 * to the ipv6_pools and the allowability of this pool for a given
1719 * client via the permit lists and the valid TIMEs.
1720 *
1721 */
1722
1723struct ipv6_pond {
1724 int refcnt;
1725 struct ipv6_pond *next;
1726 struct group *group;
1727 struct shared_network *shared_network; /* backpointer to the enclosing
1728 shared network */
1729 struct permit *permit_list; /* allow clients from this list */
1730 struct permit *prohibit_list; /* deny clients from this list */
1731 TIME valid_from; /* deny pool use before this date */
1732 TIME valid_until; /* deny pool use after this date */
1733
1734 struct ipv6_pool **ipv6_pools; /* NULL-terminated array */
1735 int last_ipv6_pool; /* offset of last IPv6 pool
1736 used to issue a lease */
1737 isc_uint64_t num_total; /* Total number of elements in the pond */
1738 isc_uint64_t num_active; /* Number of elements in the pond in use */
1739 isc_uint64_t num_abandoned; /* count of abandoned leases */
1740 int logged; /* already logged a message */
1741 isc_uint64_t low_threshold; /* low threshold to restart logging */
1742 int jumbo_range;
1743#ifdef EUI_64
1744 int use_eui_64; /* use EUI-64 address assignment when true */
1745#endif
1746};
1747
1748/*
1749 * Max addresses in a pond that can be supported by log threshold
1750 * Currently based on max value supported by isc_uint64_t.
1751*/
1752#define POND_TRACK_MAX ISC_UINT64_MAX
1753
1754/* Flags for dhcp_ddns_cb_t */
1755#define DDNS_UPDATE_ADDR 0x0001
1756#define DDNS_UPDATE_PTR 0x0002
1757#define DDNS_INCLUDE_RRSET 0x0004
1758#define DDNS_CONFLICT_DETECTION 0x0008
1759#define DDNS_CLIENT_DID_UPDATE 0x0010
1760#define DDNS_EXECUTE_NEXT 0x0020
1761#define DDNS_ABORT 0x0040
1762#define DDNS_STATIC_LEASE 0x0080
1763#define DDNS_ACTIVE_LEASE 0x0100
1764#define DDNS_DUAL_STACK_MIXED_MODE 0x0200
1765#define DDNS_GUARD_ID_MUST_MATCH 0x0400
1766#define DDNS_OTHER_GUARD_IS_DYNAMIC 0x0800
1767
1768#define CONFLICT_BITS (DDNS_CONFLICT_DETECTION|\
1769 DDNS_DUAL_STACK_MIXED_MODE|\
1770 DDNS_GUARD_ID_MUST_MATCH|\
1771 DDNS_OTHER_GUARD_IS_DYNAMIC)
1772
1773/* States for dhcp_ddns_cb_t */
1774#define DDNS_STATE_CLEANUP 0 /* startup or the previous step failed, cleanup */
1775
1776#define DDNS_STATE_ADD_FW_NXDOMAIN 1
1777#define DDNS_STATE_ADD_FW_YXDHCID 2
1778#define DDNS_STATE_ADD_PTR 3
1779#define DDNS_STATE_DSMM_FW_ADD3 4
1780
1781#define DDNS_STATE_REM_FW_YXDHCID 17
1782#define DDNS_STATE_REM_FW_NXRR 18
1783#define DDNS_STATE_REM_PTR 19
1784#define DDNS_STATE_REM_FW_DSMM_OTHER 20
1785
1786/*
1787 * Flags for the dns print function
1788 */
1789#define DDNS_PRINT_INBOUND 1
1790#define DDNS_PRINT_OUTBOUND 0
1791
1792struct dhcp_ddns_cb;

1794typedef void (*ddns_action_t)(struct dhcp_ddns_cb *ddns_cb,
1795 isc_result_t result);
1796

1798 struct data_string fwd_name;
1799 struct data_string rev_name;
1800 struct data_string dhcid;
1801 struct iaddr address;
1802 int address_type;
1803
1804 unsigned long ttl;
1805
1806 unsigned char zone_name[DHCP_MAXDNS_WIRE];

1808 isc_sockaddr_t zone_addrs[DHCP_MAXNS];
1809 int zone_addr_count;
1810 struct dns_zone *zone;
1811
1812 u_int16_t flags;
1813 TIME timeout;
1814 int state;
1815 ddns_action_t cur_func;
1816
1817 struct dhcp_ddns_cb * next_op;
1818
1819 /* Lease or client state that triggered the ddns operation */
1820 void *lease;
1821 struct binding_scope **scope;
1822
1823 void *transaction;
1824 void *dataspace;
1825
1826 dns_rdataclass_t dhcid_class;
1827 dns_rdataclass_t other_dhcid_class;
1828 char *lease_tag;
1829 struct ia_xx *fixed6_ia;
1830} dhcp_ddns_cb_t;

3905
3906/* Find the percentage of count. We need to try two different
3907 * ways to avoid rounding mistakes.
3908 */
3909#define FIND_PERCENT(count, percent) \
3910 ((count) > (INT_MAX / 100) ? \
3911 ((count) / 100) * (percent) : ((count) * (percent)) / 100)
3912
3913#define FIND_POND6_PERCENT(count, percent) \
3914 ((count) > (POND_TRACK_MAX / 100) ? \
3915 ((count) / 100) * (percent) : ((count) * (percent)) / 100)
3916
